Question: Which of the following best describes the difference between project deliverables and project requirements?

Answers: Deliverables are specific items that must be produced to consider the project or project phase complete. A phase can have one deliverable and many requirements.
Requirements are measurable items that must be produced to consider the project or project phase complete. A phase can have multiple deliverable and many requirements.
Requirements are measurable items that must be produced to consider the project or project phase complete. Deliverables are the specifications of the product, services or result need to be delivered.

Deliverables are specific items that must be produced to consider the project or project phase complete. Requirements are the specifications of the deliverables used to tell you if the deliverables were produced successfully.

Special causes are easier to predict and handle than random causes (also called common causes).

Assumptions are sign for risk which will come when project will be executed. So you can wait till risk planning phase start.

Question: You have been assigned a project manager for an information security project. This project will help the organization is big way but since the beginning your are facing huge resistance from the people because their way of working will change once this project is complete. What shall you do?
Note: [Qno: PML_543] >> PMBOK(r) Guide 4th Edition, pages 215 and 233 (9.2.3.4).

Answers: Develop a Responsibility assignment matrix (RAM) based on RACI and inform people about this.
Develop an organization diagram which does not allow and encourage any unofficial discussion which can be fatal for project.
Do not talk to these stakeholders too much at this time, instead create Faits accomplis, which will later force the stakeholders to support the project due to a lack of alternatives for them.
Schedule a meeting with these stakeholders to present the project, discuss and establish ground rules, ensure their involvement and identify initial personal and organizational issues.

Question: What is typical for Critical chain project management?

Question: Crashing involves

Reducing the number of features of the product in order to reduce development work.
Reallocating existing resources or assigning additional resources to the project.
Reducing the duration estimates for activities to increase the pressure applied to the staff.

Phase gates are often used to verify entry criteria of a previous phase and exit criteria of the next one.

If phase gate is approaching fast then it is a sign of poor planning

Question: In you project you are using control charts to identify outliers. An outlier is ---

Insignificant results like measurement errors, the causes of which should not be further investigated.
Measurements of inconsistent with a run of 7 results over or under a mean value.
Measurements outside the bandwidth between an upper and lower control limit.

Note: [Qno: PML_780] >> Creation of deliverables is output of the Direct and Manage Project execution process.

Question: Which of the following processes is NOT in the Initiating process group?

Stop the work, right there because working after this will be waste of time and money (customer may not accept it)

Question: You are doing business in India and about to start working on a new government project. Knowing that ethics and local culture has been very sensitive issue within your company when a government agency approaches you that it is customary and basic ethics that you should return the favor. What do you do in this situation.
Note: [Qno: PML_1497] >>  This is a matter of complying with the policies, laws and regulations in the country where you are doing business; what is illegal in your country may be considered legal and ethical in another country

Answers: Report the issue to your manger and comply with official guidelines
Look for ways to help the contract facilitator and go out of the way
This is a bribe by your country’s standards - under no circumstances will you comply with the official’s request
Report the issue to Indian Intelligence Agency

Question: The project manager can perform all the following functions in a procurement except:
Note: [Qno: PML_1515] >> The PM may not be the lead negotiator in procurements. PMBOK(r) Guide 4th Edition, p. 333

Answers: Should be the lead negotiator in a procurement
Have authority to authorize changes to the procurement
Help to clarify and finalize the contract terms and conditions
Take a lead role in auditing the seller’s work product

Question: You have engaged a sole source vendor to procure a critical product for your project that is needed for your project. The vendor submits a contract which is reviewed by your legal team. While most of the provisions are agreeable, there are several questionable provisions that are clearly illegal and unenforceable in the state where the contract will be signed. The vendor has informed you that they will not provide the product or sign the contract without those questionable provisions included. The procurement of this product is critical to the survivability of your business, and time is of the essence. The vendor thinks they have advantageous position and your organization have to comply in order to complete the project. Aside from the questionable provisions in the contract, everything else in the contract is acceptable. As the buyer, your best option moving forward is to:
Note: [Qno: PML_1539] >>  This is a somewhat tricky question and it must be read carefully. Answer A does not help you if time is of the essence - litigations and additional negotiations can take quite a long time. Answer C may or may not be possible and will also take considerable additional time. Answer D would probably work, legally, but may not support the idea of ‘protecting the relationship with the seller’. However, it might become your ‘fallback’ option if B does not work. The best option, Answer B, is to point out the legal problems with the contract and appeal to the vendor’s reason. Point out that if it comes down to legal wrangling or a court case, the illegality of the specific contract provisions will be exposed and deemed unenforceable in a court of law. (Most contracts will contain a phrase that states that if any provision of the contract is deemed unenforceable in a court of law, the remaining provisions are still in force.)

Answers: Find a competing vendor that will provide an equivalent product
Initiate a legal action against the vendor for attempting to break the law
Point out that the questionable provisions are unenforceable in the state, and offer to sign the contract immediately if the provisions are removed or modified to be legal
Today you can sign the contract -  even if the questionable provisions are legally unenforceable

Question: You are managing a project in a foreign country. In this country there is a normal practice for business people to exchange gifts whenever a new project is awarded. Therefore company has guidelines to accept and pay gift of certain range without approval. You given a gift to your customer. Now customer is giving you the gift of higher value than your gift. What should you do now?

Answers: Tell your customer to give the gift to your manager.
Ask your customer to give you the gift of lower or equal value than allowed limit in your organization.
Refuse the gift graciously, explaining your company’s policy
Contact your company’s management and seek for assistance

Answers: The person or team doing the work.

Note: [Qno: PML_1756] >> “Contract negotiation clarifies the structure and requirements of the contract so that mutual agreement can be reached prior to signing the contract.” [PMBoK 12.2.2.7]

Clarify and develop a mutual agreement on the responsibilities and authorities that will govern contract administration.
Bargain with the seller with respect to resources and activities in order to come to terms that can be incorporated into the final contract.
Clarify and develop a mutual agreement on the structure and requirements of the contract.

Procurement planning should include consideration of potential subcontracts
